title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of the total number of complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. The misuse of victim's information included credit card fraud (25%), phone/utilities fraud (16%), bank fraud (16%), employment-related fraud (14%), government documents/benefits fraud (5%), loan fraud (5%), and other types of identity theft fraud (24%). Victims may suffer from damaged credit records and unauthorized charges. Identity theft complaints accounted for 24% of total complaints, leading to damaged credit records, unauthorized credit card charges, and bank withdrawals. Victims may need to change phone numbers, social security numbers, and addresses falsified by impostors. Concerns about identity theft are widespread due to data security breaches. Federal laws can help victims remove inaccurate credit information and unauthorized charges, while imposing penalties on identity thieves using fraudulent documents. This report will be updated as needed. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act imposes penalties on those who use fraudulent identification documents, including consumer identity theft. It is a federal crime to produce or possess stolen identification documents without lawful authority. Federal law prohibits the production or possession of stolen identification documents without lawful authority. It is also illegal to knowingly transfer or use another person's identification with the intent to commit unlawful activities. Punishments for fraud related to identification documents vary, with fines or imprisonment of up to 15 years possible for certain offenses. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, establishes penalties for aggravated identity theft. Offenses related to drug trafficking or violence can result in up to twenty years imprisonment, while those linked to international terrorism can lead to twenty-five years imprisonment. Aggravated identity theft involves knowingly using another person's identification during certain felonies, leading to a two-year imprisonment term. For terrorism-related offenses, an additional five years can be added. The act also mandates the United States Sentencing Commission to adjust guidelines for punishing identity theft. Additionally, appropriations were authorized for the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute such crimes. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act increased penalties for identity theft and authorized appropriations to the Justice Department for investigation and prosecution. The Fair Credit Reporting Act provides assistance to victims by allowing them to have negative information removed from their credit files. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports, permissible uses, and disclosure requirements. It requires accuracy in reported information and allows consumers to sue for violations, such as inaccurate disclosures by credit reporting agencies. Victims of identity theft can also sue for failure to verify information accuracy. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) allows consumers to sue credit reporting agencies for failing to verify information accuracy or disclosing inaccurate information due to stolen identity. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to prevent identity theft and create national standards for addressing consumer concerns. Credit card issuers must follow new FCRA procedures. Under new provisions of the FCRA, credit card issuers must follow specific procedures to prevent identity theft, such as truncating credit card account numbers on receipts and social security numbers on credit reports. Consumers can request fraud alerts in their files if they have been victims of identity theft or anticipate becoming victims. Under new provisions of the FCRA, consumers can request a fraud alert from one agency, which will notify other agencies. Fraud alerts can be maintained for 90 days or extended for up to seven years. The alert becomes part of the credit file, shared with all users, and included in credit scores. Victims of identity theft can also block information from their credit reports with appropriate proof. Upon request, consumers can block alleged fraudulent information from their credit reports by providing proof of identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies must notify the furnisher of the information and refer requests to other agencies. Victims of identity theft can also request information about the crime and businesses must provide transaction records upon verification of the victim's identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and receive proof of purchases made by impostors. It aims to protect consumers from inaccurate credit billing practices by defining billing errors and providing a procedure for resolving them. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute charges for goods or services not accepted or delivered, and to request proof of purchase. Consumers can file a claim with the creditor to resolve billing errors, and until resolved, they are not required to pay the disputed amount. The creditor must investigate and correct any billing errors, including crediting the consumer's account for the disputed amount and finance charges. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) provides consumers with a mechanism to challenge unauthorized transactions and limit liability for unauthorized electronic fund transfers. If a consumer reports the loss or theft of a debit card within two business days, their liability is limited to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before notification. Financial institutions must provide documentation of electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. If an error is reported within 60 days, the institution must investigate and report the results within 10 business days. Consumer must provide account details, error belief, and amount for investigation. Financial institutions are required to identify consumer's name and account number, investigate reported errors within 60 days, and correct errors within one day of determination. Provisional recrediting of consumer's account is allowed if investigation cannot be completed within 10 business days. President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft in April 2007. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan in April 2007 to combat identity theft within 10 business days. The plan focuses on government resources to crack down on criminals trafficking in stolen identities, strengthening efforts to protect personal information, assisting law enforcement in investigating and prosecuting identity thieves, educating consumers and businesses on protection, and increasing safeguards on personal data. Recommendations include improving data security and education, making it harder for identity thieves to obtain consumer data, aiding victims in recovery, and deterring theft through aggressive prosecution. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended amendments to federal criminal statutes to prosecute identity theft-related offenses more effectively. Recommendations include adding new crimes to the list of predicate offenses for aggravated identity theft, penalizing creators of malicious spyware, and ensuring identity thieves can be prosecuted for misappropriating information from corporations and organizations. The cyber-extortion statute should cover more types of cyber-extortion, and sentences for identity theft should be enhanced for affecting multiple victims. The Real ID Rule, in accordance with the REAL ID Act of 2005, sets standards for issuing driver's licenses and identification cards to meet federal requirements. The Real ID Rule sets security standards for driver's licenses and identification cards, with deadlines for compliance and extensions granted to states meeting benchmarks. The rule is effective from March 31, 2008, with deadlines for card replacement by December 1, 2014, and December 1, 2017, based on birth dates.
